security: Disclosing information about Soviet submarine capabilities and US intelligence gathering methods could compromise national security. The document itself states: "The SPECIAL REPORT contains classified information affecting the national security of the United States within the meaning of the espionage laws, US Code Title 18, Sections 793, 794, and 798."
summary: This CIA Special Report from September 1968 reviews the developing Soviet submarine force, detailing their fleet modernization, operational implications, deployment patterns, and patrol activity, as well as technological advances in submarine support.
summary_one_paragraph: This Top Secret CIA Special Report, dated September 13, 1968, provides an overview of the Soviet Union's submarine force, focusing on its modernization efforts including the introduction of new classes like the Y-class ballistic missile submarine, advancements in nuclear-powered attack submarines, and the reconditioning of older vessels; it assesses the strategic implications of these developments, noting the increased range of Soviet missiles and the potential threat to US Polaris bases; the report also examines deployment patterns across the Northern, Pacific, Baltic, and Black Sea fleets, highlighting patrol activities and the use of floating support bases; finally, it touches on technological improvements such as new radio transmitters and navigation satellite systems enhancing Soviet submarine capabilities.
title: SPECIAL REPORT--WEEKLY REVIEW: The Developing Soviet Submarine Force
